subject: Education
title: Credentialing in the Future: Degrees vs. Skills
description: A quick, practical guide to Credentialing in the Future: Degrees vs. Skills.

hook.text: Google, Apple, and IBM stopped requiring degrees. They test skills instead.

buildup.text: The four-year degree has been the default credential for decades, but alternatives are multiplying.

discovery.text: Micro-credentials, badges, and skill assessments promise to measure what you can do, not where you went.

twist.text: Employers still use degrees as a filterâ€”not because they prove learning, but because they signal persistence.

climax.text: The future likely holds a mix: foundational degrees plus stackable micro-credentials for specific skills.

punchline.text: The question is shifting from 'where did you study?' to 'what can you do?'

quiz.question: Why do some major companies no longer require college degrees?
options: They prefer testing actual skills and abilities directly
College graduates perform worse at every task
Government regulations require them to hire non-graduates
